statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: San Francisco 58, Portland 56
article.story: PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- Tyrone Riley had 24 points, including a clutch 3-pointer with 20 seconds left, to lead San Francisco to 58-56 victory over Portland on Thursday. Riley had only six points in the second half, but he scored when his team needed it the most. His 3-pointer, which he banked in under heavy defensive pressure, gave the Dons the lead for good at 57-56. When the two teams met in San Francisco earlier in the year, Riley hit a 3-pointer that sent the game into overtime. The Dons went on to win that contest by four points. This time, Portland had two chances in the final seconds to either tie or take the lead, but came up empty both times. On the first possession, Ben Sullivan threw away an inbounds pass and the Pilots had to foul John Cox, who hit one of two free throws to give San Francisco a 58-56 lead with five seconds left to play. Pooh Jeter turned the ball over with one second left as he tried to drive the lane for the tying basket. San Francisco had a 32-25 first half lead, but the margin could have been larger after Portland shot only 4-of-25 from the field. It was Portland's worst first-half shooting performance since a December 2003 game at Duke, when the Pilots hit 3-of-28 shots. Cox, who entered the game as the league's leading scorer, had 14 points, but made only 5-of-20 shot attempts. Jeter led the Pilots with 14 points.
